Award.AwardTitle: Role Of A Lys63-Specific E2 Ubiquitin-Conjugating Enzyme/Variant In Plant Innate Immunity
Award.AbstractNarration: Ubiquitination is a major eukaryotic protein modification process that attaches ubiquitin, a highly conserved small protein, to substrates. The ubiquitination process involves three consecutive enzymatic reactions that are catalyzed by ubiquitin-activating enzyme (E1), ubiquitin-conjugating enzyme (E2) and ubiquitin ligase (E3), respectively. In recent years, ubiquitination has emerged as a key regulatory mechanism of plant immunity against many pathogens. Several plant E3 ligases have been shown to act as either positive or negative regulators of host immunity and immunity-associated cell death. In contrast, roles of E2 enzymes in plant immunity, particularly those that direct non-classical lysine 63-specific ubiquitination, are virtually unknown. Opening a new perspective on plant immunity, the investigators have implicated in tomato defense against a bacterial pathogen an E2 ubiquitin-conjugating enzyme that directs lysine 63-specific ubiquitination. In this project the investigators will characterize key components of lysine 63-linked ubiquitination in plant immunity, which is of fundamental importance to the understanding of the regulation of plant immunity by the ubiquitination system. Additionally, this work will assist in efforts to unravel biological processes and proteins that are controlled by lysine 63-linked ubiquitination, knowledge of which is very limited at present. Integral to this project is training of post-doctoral, graduate and undergraduate students from minority groups that are underrepresented in science; incorporation of findings from this project to a dual-listed undergraduate-/graduate-level laboratory course taught at the PI's institution, where minority students currently make up over 30% of the student population; and partnering of the investigators with the Arkansas Cooperative Extension Service to distribute findings from this project to the general public and stakeholders.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The annual loss in crop yield caused by plant diseases are in the value of billions of dollars in the United States and worldwide. Elucidating and eventually manipulating for crop improvement the key molecular mechanisms that plants use to defend themselves against microbial pathogens is thus of great agricultural, social and economic significance. Notably, the importance of ubiquitination - a major post-translational protein modification process occurs in eukaryotic cells - in the regulation of plant immunity against many pathogens has been increasingly appreciated in the past decade. Nevertheless, lysine-63 (K63)-linked ubiquitination has been extremely understudied despite that it has been shown to be the second most abundant among many different types of ubiquitination that occur in plant cells. There was a significant knowledge gap regarding K63-linked ubiquitination in the regulation of plant immunity before the start of this project, which was in sharp contrast to the fact that key regulatory roles for K63-linked ubiquitination in modulating innate and adaptive immunity was well documented in humans and animals then.

 

This project aimed to help fill the knowledge gap. Towards that end, we employed the tomato-Pseudomonas syringae pv tomato (Pst) pathosystem and Nicotiana benthamiana, a species related to tomato for our study. We identified the tomato ubiquitin-conjugating enzyme, Fni3 as an interacting protein of Fen, a protein kinase that works together with another tomato protein Prf in mediating plant resistance against Pst infection. We revealed that Fni3 and its homolog in tomato, Ubc13-2 (SlUbc13-2) work with the ubiquitin-conjugating enzyme variant, Suv to direct K63-linked ubiquitination. We unraveled that Fni3/Suv act as a positive regulator of immunity-associated cell death triggered by Fen and several other plant immunity elicitors, which for the first time directly implicated plant K63-linked ubiquitination in host immunity. These findings were published at a high-ranking international journal, testifying their novelty and impact. Additionally, we identified in this project nine tomato Fni3-interacting (Fti) proteins, among which six are ubiquitin ligases. We confirmed that four of the Fti ubiquitin ligases catalyze K63-linked ubiquitination. In particular, we discovered that tomato Fti1 and its homolog Fti1B as well as Fti9 are involved in plant immunity. We also found the closest Arabidopsis homolog of Fti1 and Fti1B, AtFti1 and AtFti1B, respectively catalyze K63-linked ubiquitination; AtFti1B interacts with a plant immune receptor; both AtFti1 and AtFti1B are involved in bacterial flagellin-triggered immunity; and the function of tomato Fti1B and Arabidopsis AtFti1B in plant immunity is conserved. These data provided critical inroads into further understanding of the molecular basis underlying the regulation of plant immunity by K63-linked ubiquitination.

 

In addition to intellectual advances, this project contributed to STEM workforce development by providing much-needed training to three postdoctoral scholars, three graduate students, nine undergraduate students, and one high school student. Of the nine undergraduate students trained, six are female and six are from minority groups that are underrepresented in science and one won the first place prize in Plant Biology subcategory at the Emerging Researchers National (ERN) Conference in Science, Technology, Engineering and Math that was held at Washington D.C. in April 2014. Findings from this project has been included in teaching materials for two graduate and undergraduate courses (~ 90 students). Our findings have also been disseminated to the plant research community by presenting at local, national and international conferences and invited talks at other institutions. This project was conducted first at the University of Arkansas at Little Rock and then transferred to the University of Nebraska-Lincoln in September 2014.
